subject: Re: [junit] Re: What's the deal with the frog?
msgSnippet: ... That *would* be cool. Creating a couple of junit tests of my own has dramatically revealed how few of the corner conditions actually get described in the
messageBody:
Mike Clark wrote:

> I've often thought a "Tested with JUnit" graphic would be cool. If
> you saw it on a project's web page, for example, then you'd assume
> there were JUnit tests you could run. Perhaps that graphic could be a
> recognizable variation of the standard logo.

That *would* be cool. Creating a couple of junit tests of my own has
dramatically revealed how few of the corner conditions actually get
described in the APIs. I'm convinced that the real story about "how it
works" is going to be recorded in the tests -- which will be a lot
easier
to read than the code -- so I'd be inclined to prefer a "tested with
junit"
API:
a) for its presumed reliability,
b) for the extra documentation, and
c) for the existence of code I could immediately experiment with
in my debugger to see how things work.
